segment.source: User Account Control Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users security policy setting.

segment.source: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users
segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy setting determines the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.
segment.target: This policy setting determines the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Automatically deny elevation requests
segment.target: Automatically deny elevation requests

segment.source: This option returns an “Access denied” error message to standard users when they try to perform an operation that requires elevation of privilege.
segment.target: This option returns an “Access denied” error message to standard users when they try to perform an operation that requires elevation of privilege.

segment.source: Most organizations that run desktops as standard users configure this policy to reduce Help Desk calls.
segment.target: Most organizations that run desktops as standard users configure this policy to reduce Help Desk calls.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: This is the default.
segment.target: This is the default.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a different user name and password.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a different user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials
segment.target: Prompt for credentials

segment.source: An operation that requires elevation of privilege prompts the user to type an administrative user name and password.
segment.target: An operation that requires elevation of privilege prompts the user to type an administrative user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: Configure the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users to Automatically deny elevation requests.
segment.target: Configure the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users to Automatically deny elevation requests.

segment.source: This setting requires the user to log on with an administrative account to run programs that require elevation of privilege.
segment.target: This setting requires the user to log on with an administrative account to run programs that require elevation of privilege.

segment.source: As a security best practice, standard users should not have knowledge of administrative passwords.
segment.target: As a security best practice, standard users should not have knowledge of administrative passwords.

segment.source: However, if your users have both standard and administrator-level accounts, set Prompt for credentials so that the users do not choose to always log on with their administrator accounts, and they shift their behavior to use the standard user account.
segment.target: However, if your users have both standard and administrator-level accounts, set Prompt for credentials so that the users do not choose to always log on with their administrator accounts, and they shift their behavior to use the standard user account.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default values

segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.target: Default value

segment.target: Default Domain Policy

segment.target: Default Domain Controller Policy

segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.
segment.target: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.

segment.source: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).
segment.target: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: One of the risks that the UAC feature tries to mitigate is that of malicious programs running under elevated credentials without the user or administrator being aware of their activity.
segment.target: One of the risks that the UAC feature tries to mitigate is that of malicious programs running under elevated credentials without the user or administrator being aware of their activity.

segment.source: This setting raises awareness to the user that a program requires the use of elevated privilege operations, and it requires that the user supply administrative credentials for the program to run.
segment.target: This setting raises awareness to the user that a program requires the use of elevated privilege operations, and it requires that the user supply administrative credentials for the program to run.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Configure the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users to Automatically deny elevation requests.
segment.target: Configure the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users to Automatically deny elevation requests.

segment.source: This setting requires the user to log on with an administrative account to run programs that require elevation of privilege.
segment.target: This setting requires the user to log on with an administrative account to run programs that require elevation of privilege.

segment.source: As a security best practice, standard users should not have knowledge of administrative passwords.
segment.target: As a security best practice, standard users should not have knowledge of administrative passwords.

segment.source: However, if your users have both standard and administrator-level accounts, we recommend setting Prompt for credentials so that the users do not choose to always log on with their administrator accounts, and they shift their behavior to use the standard user account.
segment.target: However, if your users have both standard and administrator-level accounts, we recommend setting Prompt for credentials so that the users do not choose to always log on with their administrator accounts, and they shift their behavior to use the standard user account.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Users must provide administrative passwords to run programs with elevated privileges.
segment.target: Users must provide administrative passwords to run programs with elevated privileges.

segment.source: This could cause an increased load on IT staff while the programs that are affected are identified and standard operating procedures are modified to support least privilege operations.
segment.target: This could cause an increased load on IT staff while the programs that are affected are identified and standard operating procedures are modified to support least privilege operations.

segment.target: Related topics
